contentrichtext.text: {{coord|1|17|04.2|N|103|50|57.6|E|display=title}} [[Image:Yueh Hai Ching Temple 6, Mar 06.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Yueh Hai Ching Temple]] '''Yueh Hai Ching Temple''' ([[Simplified Chinese|Chinese]]: 粤海清庙), also known as ''Wak Hai Cheng Bio'' in Teochew, is a [[China|Chinese]] [[temple]] in [[Singapore]], and is located at [[Phillip Street]] in the [[Downtown Core]], within the [[Central Area]], Singapore's [[central business district]]. Yueh Hai Ching Temple is Singapore's oldest [[Taoist]] temple. It was constructed between 1850 and 1855, and was rebuilt in 1895. The temple holds a special significance for the [[Chaozhou|Teochew]] community, whose way of life was closely associated with the [[sea]]. It is the only temple in Singapore to have stunningly detailed three-dimensional [[Molding (decorative)|moulded]] [[Ornament (architecture)|ornament]]s on its [[roof]]s. [[Emperor of China|Chinese Emperor]] [[Guang Xu]] presented a [[Commemorative plaque|plaque]] to the temple in 1907.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_327_2005-01-18.html | title=Yue Hai Ching Temple | publisher=[[National Library Board]] | accessdate=December 09, 2012}}</ref> Restoration works, slated to begin after Chinese New Year in February 2011, will be carried out on the Yueh Hai Ching Temple's entire structure. [[Ngee Ann Kongsi]], which owns the temple, will be committing $5 million to its restoration.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/CCMG.SI/key-developments/article/2443404 | title=CCM Group Ltd's CCM Industrial Pte. Ltd. Secures New Contract Worth SGD5.9 Million | publisher=Reuters | accessdate=December 09, 2012}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} 2. National Heritage Board (2002), ''Singapore's 100 Historic Places'', Archipelago Press, ISBN 981-4068-23-3 <br> 3. Lee Geok Boi (2002), ''The Religious Monuments of Singapore'', Landmark Books, ISBN 981-3065-62-1 <br> 4.
